opener.dateline: Black Castle / I stay here till Decr. 1st Novr. 7th 1826

div.p:
Surely my dear Mrs Brinkley you know as
well as if you were with their side of me that
I have the warmest interest in all that
has happened and have been feeling
for you and with you - though I have not
written to say so - I have seen all your letters
- know all you have said - done - felt -
thought - and love you all the better -

Now that the first tide of congratulations
have passed over, and that the overwhelming
truth has subsided you can have time for
mine - most sincere - most cordial they
are-

All things considered - and balanced
I can honestly tell you that I do believe you will
be as happy in a palace as you were have been
in the observatory - more I cannot say - and
you will feel that this is saying quite enough
- I wish ... (Doctor Brinkley's) I was going to say
I mean the Bishop of Cloyne's parting with
his instrument were well over - and your
parting with your daughter - you can neither
of you bear to hear me mention these things - but
I am doing you a service - It is surprising how

the mind learns to submit to necessity - and when
we have heard and said to ourselves repeatedly
that any anything must be the must be at last becomes
easy - at least to good & well regulated minds-

I was delighted to hear through Mrs Edgeworth
the description of your new residence - the palace
built by bits at such different times by such
different people with the different views of what
is necessary for living according to the progress of
refinement & luxury - I am glad you have
good gardens - that will be a great source of
pleasure to you all - to you especially.

I heard of your most hospitable wish to receive
us all in your new palace some time or other
and I assure you I look forward to the possibility
as one great pleasure in store for us in future
life

Mrs Edgeworth had the joy of passing a few
days with Harriet Butler at the Vicarage at Town
- I know how sincerely you all love her and
you would I am sure be delighted to see how
happily she is established - married to a man
who appreciates all her qualities & (may I say) ta-
lents talents - who has literary tastes and loves her the
more for having them & whose strict integrity &
truth of character in small things as well as great
peculiarly suit her own habits and principles -
Their tempers too are excellently suited -
tho though
one is lively & the

other grave - one remarkably active - the other slow
to rouse - I did not say indolent - quite did I?-
- often the differences of character make people suit
all the better for living together - defects in one are
felt to be compensated by the other & deficiencies supplied
on each side happily - for which both are grateful
to each other - & life goes on better than if both
were perfect - after all who is?- -

Tell me now I pray you as much as you can
of yourselves and of Mrs.. Graves - that I may feel
that I have not been too guilty of that family =
egotism for which I believe we Edgeworths are
infamous - Show me that your heart overflows to
mine as mine does to you - My most affection
and congratulations to the Bishop - No
- or fortune can add to the respect
I have always felt for him
div.closer:
Yours my dear Mrs Brinkley
sincerely & affectionately
Maria Edgeworth -

postscript.p:
I have heard from Francis & from Triny Coll.
Cambridge where he is comfortably settled - He
writes in good spirits and as if he was taking
to the place kindly - He likes his tutor - Thorpe -
as well as he can judge on a weeks acquaintance
-pays 14
sh
shillings a week for his lodgings - & has bought
describes his legs & arms at war with his new gown
cups & saucers & honey=dish too & made a most
entertaining & interesting letter of all these petty concerns

-Well for those who can write & do write all that comes
uppermost to their own family - That kind of openness &
playfulness is always a good symptom - & a good
safeguard - Nonsense - and art - seldom go
together - except in Cromwell - and a few others
- but theirs was not playful nonsense - but hy
pocritical hypocritical slang -
I feel very much afraid for our dear friend Sir Walters
life of Bonaparte Buonaparte
- I wish he never had undertaken
it - History shd
should not be sent sheet by sheet fresh
from the pen to the press - I hope that is only a
newspaper lie - He shd
should contradict it - or some friend
rather shd
should contradict it for him -
